case_data.name: Crudup v. Government of District of Columbia
case_data.plaintiff_description: Four individuals, suing on behalf of themselves and other Black residents who were stopped and frisked by the Metropolitan Police Department.
case_data.summary:
โโThis case concerned the constitutionality of the Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia ("MPD")’s stop-and-frisk policy. MPD’s special Gun Recovery Unit ("GRU") finds and recovers illegal firearms. Three Black individuals who were stopped and frisked by the GRU brought a class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia on April 30, 2020. They sued the District of Columbia under 42 U.S.C. § 1983. Represented by private counsel, the plaintiffs alleged that the GRU violated the Fourth Amendment by stopping, frisking, arresting, and detaining individuals without reasonable suspicion or probable cause; fabricated facts to retroactively justify reasonable suspicion; and specifically targeted Black individuals for searches in violation of the Fifth Amendment’s Equal Protection provision. The plaintiffs requested damages for injuries suffered by the named plaintiffs and members of the class, injunctive and declaratory relief, and attorneys’ fees. The case was assigned to District Judge Tanya S. Chutkan.

The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on September 30, 2020, which added a fourth named plaintiff and alleged that the defendant failed to adequately screen, train, supervise, and discipline MPD officers. The amended complaint also added nine individual MPD officers as defendants (in their individual and official capacities) and requested punitive damages from each of them.

On November 16, 2020, the District of Columbia moved to dismiss the amended complaint.

Judge Chutkan denied the District of Columbia's motion to dismiss on March 29, 2023. The court held that the plaintiffs sufficiently alleged that the GRU officers acted with racially discriminatory intent and lacked the requisite reasonable suspicion to stop and search named plaintiffs. Judge Chutkan also held that the MPD officers were not entitled to qualified immunity because a reasonable police officer would understand that stopping and searching someone without reasonable suspicion or probable cause is unlawful. Lastly, the court found that the plaintiffs sufficiently established the District of Columbia's municipal liability. 

On January 31, 2024, the parties filed a joint motion for a referral to a magistrate judge for mediation; the parties also moved to stay. Judge Tanya Chutkan granted the joint motion on February 6, 2024, and the case was referred to Magistrate Judge Moxila Upadhyaya for mediation. All deadlines were stayed. 

On June 5, the parties reached a settlement. The terms of the settlement are unknown to the Clearinghouse at this time. Judge Chutkan ordered the parties to file a stipulation of dismissal or joint status report on or before July 8, 2024. The case was dismissed on June 24, 2024.

COMPLAINT AND JURY DEMAND 
(ยง 1983 Civil Rights Claims) 
Introduction 
1.  Dalonta Crudup, Dontrey Bell, and David Burns (sometimes the โNamed 
Plaintiffsโ), on behalf of themselves and the classes defined below, bring this action against the 
Government of the District of Columbia (the โDistrictโ or the โDistrict of Columbiaโ) under 42 
U.S.C.A. ยง 1983 for injuries they suffered during the Class Period because the District, through its 
policy of stopping, frisking and searching African American people (especially young African 
American men) looking for guns without reasonable suspicion or probable cause, fabricating facts 
to justify the stops, frisks and searches, and intentionally discriminating on the basis of race through 
its Gun Recovery, violated their Fourth and Fifth Amendment rights. 
Jurisdiction and Venue 
2.  This Court has jurisdiction over the Named Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 claims under 28 
U.S.C.A. ยง1331 and 28 U.S.C.A. ยง1343(3)-(4). 
3.  Venue is proper in this jurisdiction pursuant to 28 U.S.CA. ยง1391(b) because the 
events or omissions underlying the claims occurred in this judicial district.  
Parties 
4.   Named Plaintiffs and the members of the proposed classes are African American 
persons who were stopped, frisked and searched for guns by the Districtโs Gun Recovery Unit 
without reasonable suspicion or probable cause, some of whom were arrested, charged or arrested 
and charged, and detained, and prosecuted in violation of their Second, Fourth, and Fifth 
Amendment rights. 
5.  Defendant the Government of the District of Columbia is a municipal corporation 
capable of being sued under D.C. Code ยง 1-102. 
Page 2 

Case 1:20-cv-01135   Document 1   Filed 04/30/20   Page 3 of 28
6.  Chief Peter Newsham is not a defendant in this lawsuit, but Chief Peter Newsham is the 
policymaker for the District of Columbiaโs MPD (Metropolitan Police Department (โMPDโ), a 
department of the government of the District of Columbia. Mayor Muriel Bowser appointed Chief 
Newsham Interim Chief of Police on September 15, 2016; he was named Chief of the 
Metropolitan Police Department on February 23, 2017 and sworn in on May 2, 2017. Chief Peter 
Newsham is not a defendant in this lawsuit. 
7.  The Gun Recovery Unit is not a defendant but the Gun Recovery Unit is a special MPD 
police unit that focuses on the interdiction and recovery of illegal firearms, and the apprehension 
of individuals involved in illegal gun crime. The Gun Recovery Unit focuses its efforts almost 
exclusively on African Americans. 
Factual Allegations 
The District and its War on Guns and Young African American Men Who Might Carry Them   
8.  In the hope of ending violent crime, the District of Columbia declared war on guns by 
enacting some of the strictest gun control measures in the country. Under this policy the Districtโs 
gun control measures amounted to a total ban on the ownership by everyone except law 
enforcement officers. But, in 2007 the Supreme Court invalidated the Districtโs approach by 
holding that the Second Amendment guarantees an individual right to keep and bear arms and that 
the core of the right is the right to self-defense. The District continued to deny handguns to people 
within its borders. In 2014 a district court Judge declared the Districtโs gun laws a total ban on 
carrying guns outside the home and thus unconstitutional under the Second Amendment. The 
D.C. Council replaced the total ban with another total ban on carrying guns outside the home 
which the D.C. Circuit struck down in 2017. Disregarding these changes in the law the District 
through its Gun Recovery Unit has continued its practice and custom of treating African American 
people as though they all carry illegal handguns.   
Page 3 

Case 1:20-cv-01135   Document 1   Filed 04/30/20   Page 4 of 28
9.  Despite its laudable mission of ending gun violence, the District through its Gun Recovery 
Unit has taken a meat axe to a problem that calls for a scalpel because in its zeal to find and 
confiscate illegal guns the Gun Recovery Unit has declared war on the African American citizens in 
the District, especially young African American men.  
10.  Moreover, the Gun Recovery Unit refuses to accept that changes in the law required by the 
Supreme Court and it continues to treat gun possession โ especially gun possession by African 
Americans โ as presumptively illegal. 
11.  The District's Gun Recovery Unit relies on the latitude afforded by voluntary consent to 
facilitate both suspicionless "consented" searches and Terry seizures premised on purportedly 
reasonable suspicions. But in the particulars of its application, the District's policy perverts the logic 
underlying Terry. 
12.  Moreover, the Gun Recovery Unit also carries out its mission by fabricating the reasonable 
suspicion or probable cause required by the Constitution to stop and frisk or search people whom

MEMORANDUM OPINION  
Plaintiffs Dalonta Crudup, Dontrey Bell, David Burns, and Joevantae Ramsey bring this 
case, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, against the District of Columbia 
and District of Columbia Metropolitan Police Department (โMPDโ) Officers Sherman Anderson, 
Eddie Choi, Brandon Joseph, Christina Laury, Mark Minzak, Justin Rogers, Iatezaz Tariq, 
Nelson Torres, and John Wright.  Plaintiffs, who are all Black males, seek to hold the MPD 
officers individually liable, and the District municipally liable, pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, for 
violating Plaintiffsโ constitutional rights and for alleged injuries from the Districtโs so-called 
โstop and friskโ policy of searching young Black males for guns, without reasonable suspicion or 
probable cause.  Defendants have moved to dismiss all claims.  Defs. Mot. to Dismiss, ECF No. 
22.  For reasons set forth below, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss will be DENIED. 
I.  BACKGROUND 
Plaintiffs claim that MPDโs Gun Recovery Unit (GRU), tasked with recovery of illegal 
firearms and apprehending individuals involved in gun related crime, unlawfully targets 
predominately Black neighborhoods and young Black males specifically.  See Am. Compl. ยถยถ 
Page 1 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 2 of 25
16โ19, 23, 27โ28, ECF No. 14.  They claim that the District has โestablished practices and 
procedures of several armed officers surrounding Black suspects without reasonable suspicion of 
a crimeโ to โintimidate suspects into consenting to a search that otherwise lacks reasonable 
suspicion for a stop.โ  Id. ยถยถ 20โ21 (internal quotation marks omitted).  Plaintiffs further accuse 
the GRU of โfabricating the reasonable suspicion or probable causeโ required to conduct a search 
or seizure.  Id. ยถ 22. 
Plaintiffs claim the GRU consists of twenty to thirty officers, one or more detectives, and 
three sergeants, who report to the Narcotics and Special Investigations Division (NSID), which 
was headed by former MPD Chief Peter Newsham when he was Assistant Chief.  Id. ยถยถ 5, 25โ
26.  Plaintiffs allege that GRU officers are โhighly aggressiveโ and forceful in their policing 
approach and are โdeployed in a manner calculated to convey force and authority well beyond 
that of an ordinary officer deployed in uniform.โ  Id. ยถยถ 33โ34.  GRU deploys โwith numerosity 
of force,โ they wear โtactical gearโ instead of a โstandard uniform,โ their โ[w]eapons are on 
displayโ when they engage with civilians, and they use โjump outsโ to convey force.  Id. ยถยถ 35โ
38.  The GRU banner and flag displays an image of skull and crossbones with a โbullet hole 
quite literally, dead-center in the forehead of the skull, with two handguns and two handcuffs on 
either side above the head,โ and a ribbon that says, โVEST UP ONE IN THE CHAMBER.โ  Id. 
ยถยถ 41โ48.  These images depict the GRUโs intentionally cultivated image, designed to โinflict 
terror on low-income communities of color,โ especially Black communities.  Id. ยถ 50.  The GRU 
officers โcelebrate their abusive authority over young [B]lack men,โ as depicted by a MPD 
officer t-shirt that says, in part, โLet me see that waistband joโ and has a Sun Cross, โa racist hate 
symbol.โ  Id. ยถยถ 63โ69.  
Page 2 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 3 of 25
Plaintiffs allege that โ[a]s a matter of policy and practice, the GRU does not require its 
officers to possess reasonable articulable suspicion in order to approach and engage civilians,โ 
and the policy is so โovert that it has been repeatedly acknowledged by District of Columbia 
Courts.โ  Id. ยถยถ 53โ58 (citing United States v. Gross, 784 F.3d 784, 789 (D.C. Cir. 2015) (J. 
Brown concurring); Robinson v. United States, 76 A.3d 329 (D.C. 2013)).  To the extent that 
officers bother to โformulate a request for a search in words nominally providing cover as a 
consensual request,โ suspects have โlittle choiceโ but to comply.  Am. Compl. ยถยถ 62, 70.  
Refusing an officer can lead to โdangerous or forceful consequences,โ and ultimately the GRU 
โwill compel the search anyways justifying the compelled search based on natural reactions to 
the aggressive officer approach or based on fabrications.โ  Id. ยถยถ 73โ74. 
Plaintiffs claim that in testimony before the D.C. Council on January 16, 2020, MPD 
Sergeant Charlotte Djossou confirmed MPDโs policy, practice, or custom of racially targeting 
Black men.  Id. ยถยถ 82, 84.  Sergeant Djossou testified that she reported NSIDโs โillegal tacticsโ to 
her supervisorsโincluding that officers were โviolating 4th Amendment rightsโโand was met 
with retaliation.  Id. ยถ 85.  In June 2018, she escalated her complaints to then Assistant Chief 
Robert Contee, who also retaliated against her.  Id. ยถ 86.   
Plaintiffs further claim that a June 13, 2018 GRU operation in the Deanwood 
neighborhood is an โillustrative exampleโ of the GRUโs โmodus operandi of stop and frisk.โ  Id. 
ยถ 88.  They contend that on that day, the GRU โstaged a fake search and find operationโ on a 
group of Black men who were sitting outside a barbershop.  Id. ยถยถ 89, 91.  GRU officers 
searched a man โwho was ostensibly a member of the group but was in fact a plant . . . so they 
could find a gun and thus manufacture reasonable suspicion to search the other men.โ  Id. ยถ 91.   
Page 3 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 4 of 25
Plaintiffs allege that despite the fact that from 2013 to 2017 forty-seven percent of D.C.โs 
population was Black, Black individuals made up eighty-six percent of total arrestees, seventy-
eight percent of arrestees for driving without a permit, were arrested at ten times the rate of 
White individuals, and disproportionately arrested in over ninety percent of census tracts.  Id. ยถยถ 
120โ22.  Plaintiffs encountered difficulty ascertaining stop and frisk data because โMPD has 
sought to avoid disclosure even of basic statisticsโ regarding its stop and frisk practices, but โ[a]s 
additional data has been produced from the Neighborhood Engagement Achieves Results 
(โNEARโ) Act of 2016, the racial disparity is clear.โ  Id. ยถยถ 95, 123.  Plaintiffs contend that the 
NEAR Act requires MPD to โcollect detailed and comprehensive data about stops and frisks the 
police carry out on the streets of the District,โ including fourteen categories of data for every 
stop.  Id. ยถยถ 96โ98.  And they allege that to the extent NEAR Act data is available, it confirms 
โextraordinary racial disparities in the MPDโs stop and frisk practices,โ id. ยถ 110:  
โข  From July 22, 2019 to August 18, 2019, ninety-three percent of frisks and eighty-seven 
percent of non-ticket (i.e., non-traffic) stops were conducted on Black individuals.  Id. ยถยถ 
113โ14.  
 
โข  From July 22, 2019 to December 31, 2019, two White individuals were stopped and 
frisked daily compared to forty-five Black individuals.  However, police discovered a gun 
in two percent of searches, and the gun recovery rate was the same regardless of whether 
the individual being searched was Black or White.  Id. ยถ 123. 
 
โข  From August 1, 2019 to January 31, 2020, eighty-eight percent of documentable stops 
and ninety-four percent of documentable searches were of Black individuals.  Id. ยถ 115.  
 
Plaintiffs also claim that television station WUSA9 and the American Civil Liberties Union have 
conducted their own analysis of NEAR Act data and/or body worn camera footage and โfound 
similar racial disparities in arrest dataโ going back as far as 2013.  Id. ยถยถ 117โ19.  On 
information and belief, Plaintiffs allege that โthe statistics for the GRUโs reported stops and frisk 
are even more extreme than the Department generally.โ  Id. ยถ 127. 
Page 4 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 5 of 25
A.  Dalonta Crudup  
Plaintiffs claim that on January 12, 2020, at around 11:30 p.m., Crudup was โwalking 
aloneโ in the 2400 block of 14th Street, N.E., wearing a coat, a hooded sweatshirt, and a 
backpack with one strap over his shoulder.  Id. ยถยถ 131, 133โ35.  Officers Choi, Minzak, Joseph, 
and Laury were driving an unmarked Chevy Malibu and approached Crudup from behind.  Id. ยถยถ 
136โ39.  The officers were not responding to a call but claim they were โseeking to match an 
individual with a recently reported crimeโ when, after observing Crudup for only a โmoment,โ 
they drove up behind him and โjumped out of their vehicle,โ dressed in โtactical gear and 
display[ing] firearms and handcuffs.โ  Id. ยถยถ 140โ42, 144โ46. 
Plaintiffs claim that Crudup lifted โhis shirt and show[ed] his waistbandโ because Black 
men in his neighborhood have no other choice when approached by GRU officers.  Id. ยถ148.  
Laury asked Crudup, โโyou donโt got no weapons on you?โโ  Id. ยถ 149.  Crudup did not respond 
but submitted to a visual search and noticed that the officers had โformed a semi-circle in front 
and around him.โ  Id. ยถยถ 149โ53.  Laury asked Crudup, โโNothing in your bag?โโ to which 
Crudup responded, โweed,โ and refused to give Laury permission to search his bag.  Id. ยถยถ 154โ
57.  At this point, Crudup was no longer โfree to leave,โ but he nonetheless โpivoted and took 
steps slowly backwards on the sidewalk away from the officers that were in the way of his path.โ  
Id. ยถยถ 158โ59.  Choi then โextended his arm to blockโ Crudupโs movement and continued to 
โintimidate[e]โ Crudup.  Id. ยถยถ 160โ61.  Choi asked if the officers could check for weapons and 
Crudup refused, but Laury โ[m]anufactur[ed] a basis to justifyโ a search and said, โโYou see the 
way you are acting is real strange, the way you are bent back across the fence back here.โโ  Id. ยถยถ 
163, 165.  
Having surrounded Crudup with โno objectively reasonable basis to suspect [he] was in 
possession of contraband,โ Officer Choi told Crudup that his backpack looked heavy.  Id. ยถยถ 166, 
Page 5 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 6 of 25
168, 170.  Crudup responded by shaking his bag, and Choi said, โโI heard an object insideโโ and 
โtook the backpack and conducted an illegal search, a pat down of the exterior of the bag.โ  Id. 
ยถยถ 170โ72.  Choi claimed to have felt more than two ounces of marijuana, searched the bag

Crudup was presented in D.C. Superior Court on January 13, 2020, preventively

Plaintiffs claim that the โfacts and the narrative the officers wove . . . in sworn statements

According to the Amended Complaint, at approximately 10:00 p.m. on April 29, 2019,

190โ91. 
Plaintiffs reference the Gerstein in Bellโs case for the arresting officerโs version of

flight up the stairsโ of the building and stopped at the top of the stairs.  Id. ยถยถ 192โ93.  Anderson 
 
1 Gerstein statements are usually prepared by an officer for use in pretrial detention decisions

A motion to dismiss under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6) โtests the legal

When considering a motion under Rule 12(b)(6), a court must construe the complaint in the light

and Plaintiffs respond that they have adequately pleaded at least three.  The court finds that 
Plaintiffs have at least pleaded Baker prongs three and four.  Accordingly, the court need not 
address whether Plaintiffs have satisfied the elements of alternative municipal liability theories.  
See Goodwin v. District of Columbia, 579 F. Supp. 3d 159, 168 (D.D.C. 2022) (โA showing 
under any of these four theories suffices to sustain a claim on Monell liability.โ (citation 
omitted)).  
i.  Knowing Failure to Act 
To establish a knowing failure to act by a policy maker, Plaintiffs must show that a 
โDistrict policymakerโs ignoring of a practice was โconsistent enough to constitute custom.โโ 
Harvey v. District of Columbia, 798 F.3d 1042, 1052โ53 (D.C. Cir. 2015) (quoting Warren v. 
District of Columbia, 353 F.3d 36, 39 (D.C. Cir. 2004)).  To clear this high hurdle, plaintiffs 
ordinarily base โcustom or practiceโ liability on allegations of โpractices so persistent and 
widespread as to practically have the force of law.โ  Page v. Mancuso, 999 F. Supp. 2d 269, 284 
(D.D.C. 2013) (quoting Connick v. Thompson, 563 U.S. 51, 61 (2011)).  Plaintiffs must also 
show that the policymaker at least had constructive knowledge of the alleged constitutional 
violations, see Baker, 326 F.3d at 1306โ07, and officers acted pursuant to the custom or policy, 
see Page, 999 F. Supp. 2d at 284.  
Plaintiffs plead numerous facts asserting that District policymakers either knew or should 
have known that the GRU was engaged in widespread Fourth Amendment violations.  Plaintiffs 
allege that MPD Sergeant Djossou complained to her command staff that โNSID officers at roll 
call were openly conversing about ways to violate [body worn camera] orders/directives,โ and 
testified at a January 16, 2020 D.C. Council hearing that NSID used โillegal tacticsโ and was 
violating individualsโ Fourth Amendment rights, and that then Assistant Chief Contee retaliated 
Page 19 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 20 of 25
against her for reporting that โlarge groups of peopleโ were being targeted โwithout probable 
cause.โ  Am. Compl. ยถยถ 82โ89.  Moreover, Plaintiffs point to the D.C. Court of Appealsโ 
decision in Robinson v. United States, 76 A.3d 329 (D.C. 2013) (internal citations omitted), as 
providing notice to Defendants that at least one GRU officer had targeted civilians for unlawful 
searches without reasonable articulable suspicion.  Am. Compl. ยถยถ 57, 76, 78.  In Robinson, 
which also involved the GRU, the D.C. Court of Appeals found that  
Officer Katz admitted he and his colleagues had no particularized information that 
Mr. Robinson might be carrying a gun when they entered the area, and Officer Katz 
developed no such thought until after he asked if Mr. Robinson had a gun and he 
observed  Mr.  Robinson  engage  in  conduct[โback  and  forth  or  side  to  side 
movement on the outside of Robinsonโs jacket in front of his chest areaโ]which, 
as we have explained, did not give rise to reasonable, articulable suspicion that Mr. 
Robinson was armed and dangerous. 
76 A.3d at 340.  Furthermore, Plaintiffs claim the GRU openly displayed flags, banners, and t-
shirts, depicting or alluding to their reputation for stopping and searching residents of the areas in 
which they operated, see Am. Compl. ยถยถ 41โ43, 51, 64 (showing photographs of these items), 
which would establish that policymakers were aware of their practices.  Lastly, Plaintiffs have 
alleged causal links between the GRUโs unconstitutional practices and the injuries Plaintiffs 
suffered from their interactions with the individual Defendants.  See Am. Compl. ยถยถ 189, 209, 
229, 270.  
ii.  Failure to Train as to Show Deliberate Indifference 
A municipality can be held liable for its โdecision not to train certain employees about 
their legal duty to avoid violating citizensโ rights.โ  Connick, 563 U.S. at 61.  To establish 
liability, a plaintiff must show that โin light of the duties assigned to specific officers or 
employees the need for more or different training is so obvious, and the inadequacy so likely to 
result in the violation of constitutional rights, that the policymakers of the city can reasonably be 
said to have been deliberately indifferent to the need.โ  City of Canton, Ohio v. Harris, 489 U.S. 
Page 20 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 21 of 25
378, 390 (1989).  Because a โmunicipalityโs culpability for a deprivation of rights is at its most 
tenuous where a claim turns on a failure to train,โ a plaintiff needs to show โpractices so 
persistent and widespread as to practically have the force of law.โ  Connick, 563 U.S. at 61 
(citation omitted).  At the motion to dismiss stage, a plaintiff must allege specific facts that 
would show deliberate indifference toward constitutional violations on the part of the municipal 
officers responsible for the policy, ordinance, custom, decision, or absence of policy.  See Bd. of 
Cty. Commโrs of Bryan Cty., Okl. v. Brown, 520 U.S. 397, 411 (1997).  โDeliberate indifference 
is determined by analyzing whether the municipality knew or should have known of the risk of 
constitutional violations, an objective standard.โ  Baker, 326 F.3d at 1307 (citing Farmer v. 
Brennan, 511 U.S. 825, 841 (1994)).  
Defendants argue that Plaintiffs cannot proceed on their failure to train theory because 
they have not shown: โ(1) a pattern of similar constitutional violations, (2) that the final 
policymaker was aware of the pattern of similar constitutional violations, and (3) that the final 
policymaker failed to properly train employees despite awareness of the constitutional 
violations.โ  Defs. Mem. at 32.  This argument is unavailing in light of โ[P]laintiffsโ many well-
pleaded allegations supporting their assertion of municipal liability against the District.โ  
Goodwin, 579 F. Supp. 3d at 169. 
The court has found that Plaintiffs have adequately alleged that policymakers either knew 
or should have known of the GRUโs unconstitutional โstop and friskโ practices.  See Supra 
Section III.C.1.i.  Plaintiffs also claim that they were searched by GRU officers without 
reasonable suspicion, that the District provided โinadequate screening, training and supervision 
of the GRU,โ and that their injuries are a direct result of that failure to train.  Am. Compl. ยถยถ 
274โ79.  Because Plaintiffs have stated predicate Fourth Amendment violations, see supra 
Page 21 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 22 of 25
Section III. B., and pleaded sufficient facts to establish that the District knew or should have 
known that GRU officers routinely violated citizensโ Fourth Amendment rights, Plaintiffs have 
made out a claim for municipal liability based on failure to train.  Therefore, Defendantsโ motion 
to dismiss as to Claim I is denied.  See Matthews v. District of Columbia, 730 F. Supp. 2d 33, 38 
(D.D.C. 2010) (holding that โgiven the variety of abuses, the number of officers, and time period 
during which these abuses allegedly took place, plaintiffs have raised an inference that the 
combination of these factors can demonstrate that the District of Columbia was deliberately 
indifferent to plaintiff's constitutional rights.โ (internal punctuation and citation omitted)); 
Moreno v. District of Columbia, 925 F. Supp. 2d 93, 101 (D.D.C. 2013) (holding that plaintiff 
stated a failure to train claim where the District failed to address plaintiffโs โspecific 
allegationsโ).   
2.  Claim II: Equal Protection and Due Process Violations 
The Equal Protection Clause applies to the District of Columbia via the Fifth 
Amendment, see Bolling v. Sharpe, 347 U.S. 497, 499 (1954), and requires state actors to treat 
similarly situated persons alike, see City of Cleburne v. Cleburne Living Ctr., Inc., 473 U.S. 432, 
439 (1985).  โThe central purpose of the Equal Protection Clause . . . is the prevention of official 
conduct discriminating on the basis of race.โ  Washington v. Davis, 426 U.S. 229, 239 (1976).  
When legislation or official action explicitly draws classifications on the basis of race, โno 
inquiry into legislative purpose is necessary,โ and strict scrutiny applies.  Hunt v. Cromartie, 526 
U.S. 541, 546 (1999).  However, when the official action is facially neutral, a trial court must 
โperform a sensitive inquiry into such circumstantial and direct evidence of intent as may be 
available.โ  Id. (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  
To prevail on an equal protection claim, a plaintiff must allege more than โracially 
disproportionate impactโโโ[p]roof of racially discriminatory intent or purpose is required.โ  
Page 22 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 23 of 25
Vill. of Arlington Heights v. Metro. Hous. Dev. Corp., 429 U.S. 252, 265 (1977).  A plaintiff can 
show discriminatory intent or purpose by presenting โevidence of discriminatory intent in the 
polic[yโs] enactmentโ or โa current pattern of disparate outcomes from which unconstitutional 
discriminatory intent could be inferred.โ  In re Navy Chaplaincy, 738 F.3d 425, 429 (D.C. Cir. 
2013).  But โ[a]bsent a pattern as stark as that in Gomillion or Yick Wo, impact alone is not 
determinative.โ  Id. (quoting Vill. of Arlington Heights, 429 U.S. at 266); see Gomillion v. 
Lightfoot, 364 U.S. 339 (1960); Yick Wo. v. Hopkins, 118 U.S. 356, 373โ74 (1886). 
In Yick Wo, the Supreme Court held that a facially neutral law granting a board of 
supervisors โnaked and arbitrary powerโ to determine who could operate certain laundry 
businesses violated the Equal Protection Clause because its effect was to prevent 200 Chinese 
persons from obtaining necessary permits, while eighty non-Chinese individuals were able to 
obtain permits.  118 U.S. at 366, 373โ74.  Similarly, in Gomillion, the Supreme Court held that 
plaintiffs had properly stated a claim where the challenged redistricting law had the effect of 
removing all but four or five of 400 Black voters from Tuskegeeโs city boundaries โwhile not 
removing a single [W]hite voter or resident.โ  364 U.S. at 341โ42.  
Plaintiffs argue that they have sufficiently alleged discriminatory intent by offering 
statistical comparisons of the rates of stops and arrests for Black individuals versus White 
individuals in the District.  See Pls.โ Oppโn at 39 (citing Marshall v. Columbia Lea Regโl Hosp., 
345 F.3d 1157, 1168 (10th Cir. 2003)).   
In Marshall, the Tenth Circuit explained that Section 1983 claims are often โbased on 
statistical comparisons between the number of black or other minority Americans stopped or 
arrested and their percentage in some measure of the relevant population.โ  345 F.3d at 1168.  It 
noted that reliance on statistical evidence to show discriminatory intent โrequires a reliable 
Page 23 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 24 of 25
measure of the demographics of the relevant population, a means of telling whether the data 
represent similarly situated individuals, and a point of comparison to the actual incidence of 
crime among different racial or ethnic segments of the population.โ  Id. (citing United States v. 
Armstrong, 517 U.S. 456, 469โ70 (1996); Chavez v. Illinois State Police, 251 F.3d 612, 640โ45 
(7th Cir. 2001)).  
Here, Plaintiffs have alleged statistics of the type described in Marshall, showing the 
disparities between MPDโs arrest and stop rates of White individuals versus Black individuals.  
They allege that ninety-three percent of stop and frisks and eighty-seven percent of non-traffic 
stops were of Black individuals, Black individuals were disproportionately arrested in ninety 
percent of census tracts and were arrested at ten times the rate of White individuals, and MPD 
searches were more likely to be conducted in Wards 7 and 8.  See Am. Compl. ยถยถ 110, 113โ14, 
120โ21.  Moreover, Plaintiffs have alleged that the GRU โis not deployed generally throughout 
all neighborhoods of Washington, D.C., which has a population that is approximately 43% 
White.  The GRU is mainly deployed in Black or African-American neighborhoods.โ  Id. ยถ 17.  
These statistics demonstrate a pattern of behavior from which an unconstitutional policy of 
discriminatory intent or purpose can be inferred. 
In Smith v. Henderson, 982 F. Supp. 2d 32, 50 (D.D.C. 2013), the court examined 
circumstances similar to those alleged here and found that the plaintiff had properly alleged an 
equal protection claim because the โlegal and factual allegations [] track the holdings of Yick Wo 
and Gomillion.โ  Smith involved the closure of fifteen public schools in the District, all of them 
in โmajority-minority neighborhoods east of Rock Creek Park,โ where โresidents are generally 
poorer and overwhelmingly black and Hispanic.โ  Id. at 39.  Plaintiff also alleged that no schools 
in majority-White parts of the city were closed.  See id.  
Page 24 of 25 
 

Case 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 28   Filed 03/29/23   Page 25 of 25
Here too, Plaintiffs have pleaded โa pattern as stark as that in Gomillion or Yick Wo;โ 
consequently, their equal protection claim survives.  In re Navy Chaplaincy, 738 F.3d at 429; see 
Smith, 982 F. Supp. 2d 32, 50 (D.D.C. 2013).   
IV.  CONCLUSION 
Having found that Plaintiffs have pleaded sufficient facts at this juncture to state their 
claims, the court will therefore DENY Defendantsโ Motion to Dismiss: ECF No. 22.

  Dalonta Crudup, Dontrey Bell, David Burns, and Joevantae Ramsey (sometimes the 
โNamed Plaintiffsโ), on behalf of themselves and the classes defined below, by and through counsel Michael 
Bruckheim, and the law office of Bruckheim & Patel, LLC,  bring this action against the Government of the District of

Officer Defendants in their individual and official capacities under 42 U.S.C.A. ยง 1983 for injuries they suffered 
during the Class Period because the District, through its policy of stopping, frisking and searching African 
American people (especially young African American men) looking for guns without reasonable suspicion

Factual Allegations 
The District and its War on Guns and Young African American Men Who Might Carry 
Them 
 
16.  The MPDโs Gun Recovery Unit (GRU) operates with an asserted purpose of removing 
illegal firearms from the streets of the District of Columbia. 
17.  The GRU, however, is not  deployed generally throughout  all neighborhoods of 
Washington, D.C., which has a residential population that is approximately 43% White. The 
GRU is mainly deployed in Black or African-American neighborhoods. 
18.  While communities in D.C., understandably seek relief and protection from gun 
related  violence,  the  predominantly  Black  neighborhoods  targeted  by  the  GRU  find 
themselves burdened by another armed force operating lawlessly and terrorizing civilians, the 
MPDโs own Gun Recovery Unit. 
19.  The District, through the GRU and in its zeal to find and confiscate illegal guns, has 
prosecuted a war on the African American citizens in the District, especially young African 
American men. 
20.  The District, through the GRU, established practices and procedures of several armed 
officers surrounding African American suspects without reasonable suspicion of a crime.   
21.  This illegal policy attempts to intimidate suspects into โconsentingโ to a search that otherwise 
 
5 

 
Ca se 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 14   Filed 09/30/20   Page 6 of 46
lacks reasonable suspicion for a stop. 
22.  Moreover, the GRU also carries out its mission by fabricating the reasonable suspicion 
or probable cause required by the Constitution to stop and frisk or search people whom the 
GRU encounters. 
GUN RECOVERY UNIT 
23.  The GRU is a special MPD police unit that focuses on the interdiction and recovery 
of illegal firearms, and the apprehension of individuals involved in illegal gun crime. The 
GRUโs stated mission is to remove firearms from the streets of the District of Columbia, 
before they can be used in a violent crime. 
24.  As detailed herein, its approaches to citizens are aggressive. 
25.  The GRU consists at any one time of twenty to thirty officers and one or more 
detectives and about three sergeants. 
26.  The GRU reports to the Narcotics and Special Investigations Division (NSID). NSID 
falls under the Investigative Services Bureau which was headed by Chief Peter Newsham 
when he was Assistant Chief. 
27.  The  District  of  Columbia  does  not  deploy  the  GRU  uniformly  across  the 
neighborhoods of the District of Columbia. 
28.  As a matter of policy, practice and/or custom, the GRU discriminatorily targets 
neighborhoods in which African-Americans or persons of color predominantly reside. 
29.  In a related matter, in connection with โFelon In Possessionโ gun prosecutions, 
Mayor Muriel E. Bowser and D.C. Police Chief Peter Newsham working with then U.S. 
Attorney for the District of Columbia jointly rolled out an initiative in February, 2019, to 
prosecute certain gun offenses in federal court, which would subject defendants to much 
 
6 

 
Ca se 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 14   Filed 09/30/20   Page 7 of 46
more severe penalties than if prosecuted in local courts. As it turns out, the โcitywideโ 
initiative, by design, targeted only predominantly Black neighborhoods (i.e., Police District 
5, 6, or 7). This targeting was nominally justified by federal authorities as โfocusing on the 
MPD districts that had the highest incidents of violent crime.โ Declaration of John Crabb, 
Jr. at 4, United States v. John Victor Reed, No. 19-cr-00093 (D.D.C. July 3, 2020), ECF No. 
48-3. In reality, this was a race-based discriminatory deployment of law enforcement 
resources. 
30.  District of Columbia officials, after over a year of such prosecutions now assert that 
they  are  shocked  to  learn  that  communities  of  color  were  discriminatorily  targeted. 
Critically, however, they do now acknowledge that such targeting of law enforcement 
resources - - even nominally focused on high crime areas - - is discriminatory. D.C. Attorney 
General Karl Racine in a statement stated โOur office was not consulted on this policy before 
it was rolled out and did not learn about its discriminatory application until the USAOโs 
[recent] public court filing.โ D.C. Council member Charles Allen has also acknowledged 
that the application of law enforcement resources in such a manner โexclusively and, now 
we know, by design โ targets District residents of color via specific police districts.โ  
31.  GRU officers, likewise, are deployed in a targeted and discriminatory manner, in 
neighborhoods of color. 
32.  The GRU further refines the civilians it targets, โmostly males in their late teens to 
early forties.โ See, e.g., United States v. Gross, 784 F.3d 784, 789 (D.C. Cir. 2015) (Brown, 
J., concurring). 
33.  The manner of GRU officersโ deployment and approach to targeted civilians is 
highly aggressive and forceful.

34.  The GRU are deployed in a manner calculated to convey force and authority well 
beyond that of an ordinary officer deployed in uniform, with a sidearm, and potentially 
with a similarly presented partner. 
35.  When engaging civilians, GRU officers typically deploy with numerosity of force, 
with several officers. 
36.  Rather than patrolling in a standard uniform, the GRU patrols in โtacticalโ gear as

37.  Weapons are on display when GRU officers approach and engage civilians. 
38.  The GRUโs forceful and aggressive use of โjump outsโ is widely known. 
39.  The GRU goes far beyond mere assertive police tactics to convey its force and 
authority. 
40.   The GRU has cultivated and developed itself as an aggressive force to which

41.  The photo below depicts members of the Gun Recovery Unit posing, in what appears

42.  The banner flag of the GRU reflects the intentionally cultivated image of their 
authority that they project to the Black community. 
43.  The following image depicts the GRUโs banner and message:

44.  This is the message the GRU sends to the community at large. The flag includes 
prominent identification of the NSID and the โGun Recovery Unitโ of โWashington, D.C.โ 
45.  The centerpiece of the GRUโs logo is a skull and crossbones, also known as the 
โDeathโs Headโ symbol. The Deathโs Head symbol has historically been used to convey 
death, danger and lawless piracy. Military units have adopted the image as a logo to denote 
their ferocity and ruthlessness. 
46.  The GRUโs logo has modified the traditional Deathโs Head by adding a bullet hole, 
quite literally, dead-center in the forehead of the skull. 
47.  Above the skullโs head are two handguns and handcuffs on either side, depicting the

48.  The ribbon displays the slogan, โVEST UP ONE IN THE CHAMBER,โ a rallying 
cry to GRU officers to have their weapons readied for a swift killing. 
49.  The MPD admitted in a statement that the above-referenced photo was publicly 
posted to a Twitter account by a GRU officer.  
50.  Law for Black Lives, the community group that filed a complaint about the GRU 
 
10 

 
Cas e 1:20-cv-01135-TSC   Document 14   Filed 09/30/20   Page 11 of 46
posted a petition that stated โThe use of this logo is part of a broader campaign designed to 
inflict terror on low-income communities of color. For the longest, community members 
have voiced their fear of the Gun Recovery Unit and concern with their policing tactics.โ  
51.  This is the well-known and apparently sanctioned reputation of the GRU, which is 
understood and implicitly conveyed every time a GRU member approaches a citizen.  
52.  Their aggressively forceful reputation is, similarly, advanced through community 
knowledge of their sheer aggressiveness, including their jump outs. 
53.  As a matter of policy and practice, the GRU does not require its officers to possess 
reasonable articulable suspicion in order to approach and engage civilians. 
54.  The policy is so overt that it has been repeatedly acknowledged by District of
